text: Bottle @ Hopfen & Malz, Berlin. Pours Dark amber with a creamy head. Chocolate, roast, bread and chewy caramel. Full bodied. Very tasty!

Bright red-gold with some fizzly foam that fades. Caramel-forward in nose and taste, with a sneaky bitterness that leaves the beer roundly balanced and more than a bit dangerous. Lacks the sort of fruity zip I want from better bock beers, but this is well made.
Reddish brown body with white head. Aroma is malts and biscuits with some bread. Taste is the same with some additional slightly roasted grains. Aftertaste is grainy and bitter.
Dunkelbräunliches Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, Karamell, schokoladig. Geschmack röstmalzig süß, minimal würzig, schokoladig.

Dunkelbrauner Bock mit beigem Schaum. Karamellmalziges Aroma. Erstaunlich leichter Antrunk. Neben dem Karamell kommt eine gewisse Zartbitterschokoladennote auf. Klingt leicht röstig aus. Ordentlich, wenn auch etwas langweilig.

bottle, courtesy of pivnizub! Clear chestnut-brown colour, mid-sized off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts and caramel. Full-bodied, malty base with quite a lot of roasted malts and chocolate, hints of coffee.
Dark amber with a short lived lightbrown head. The aroma are mostly roasted malty but also chocolate after a while.

500ml bottle. Clear dark amber colour with small frothy off-white head. Malty aroma with explicit milk chocolate note, a nougat touch, a hint of alcohol. Chocolatey malt taste, decent underlying grainy touch, husk. Well handled sweetness, a touch of roast in the end.

0.5 l bottle, thanks Timo A! Amber color. Sweet caramelly and bready aroma with nuts and diluted coffee. Bready and caramelly flavor with roasty coffeish and nutty finish. Surprising coffee finish, feels more like a strong dunkel than a bock.
Swing top bottle from Bierzwerg. Dark amber colour with medium head. Aroma is malty, Flavour is malt, sweet, not that geat bock.

(bottle) pours a clear copper colour with a frothy light beige head. aroma of grain, vanilla and grass, with hints of dark fruit and custard. flavour is mostly the same, with a hint of bread dough, tobacco and a herbal-hoppy light bitter finish, not a trace of sweetness. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

Swing top bottle 500ml (BZ, BB 07/2012)
Deep amber-ruby color, good beige head. Chocolaty, malty aroma .. kind of similar than in some artifical chocolate beers. Medium-bodied. Chocolate/cocoa and caramel, coffee in malty flavor. Weak late hoppyness. Interesting different bock but flavors are a bit unbalanced althought it has very robust malt profile.

Its beautiful mahogany-red with a creamy, golden head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, dark syrup, fruit, cocoa and light oranges. The sweet flavour has notes of licorice, fruit, oranges, dark syrup, cocoa, and the finish is dry and slightly bitter. Its remarkably well-balanced, perhaps the best bock we have tasted.

Etwas wässriger Start, verhalten malzig werdend, im Mittelteil etwas alkoholisch. Das Bier bleibt weiter wässrig und ist nur wenig würzig, auch der im Abgang auftretende Röstmalzton kann nur gering gegensteuern. 	 
Test vom 25.1.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: 11,7,8,10,7,8 - 8,40

Bottled (from bierkompass.de). Amber colour, mediumsized beige head, that leaves some lace. Aroma is chocolate, some toasted notes as well as dark fruits and caramel malts. Flavour is chocolate, some toasted notes, caramel malts and also quite bittery. Really pleasantly balanced bockbier.
Bottled 50cl. Ordered from www.bierkompass.de. Reminiscence of DMS especially in the aroma. The nose is indeed rather dissapointing. The taste is a little better. Malt accented.
Bottle. Clear amber colour. Flat carbonation, slightly sweet and malty in the beginning, becomes increasingly bitter towards the end.
plopp-bottle. dark-red colour, solid head. starts astonishingly dry, nearly bitter. malty tones in the middle, ends up with malt and hops. quite untypically but therefore interesting.

Swing top bottle. Dark brown color. Cacao, chocolate, toffee and malt in the aroma. Malty sweet flavor with dark chocolate and toffee. So thick you can almost chew on this beer. Low on carbon. Hint of laurel in the aftertaste. I just love this bock!

flip-top-bottle nearing the best before date: auburn colour, caramelly aroma, full, but not too sweet body, dried fruit (plums) and a roasted, almost smoky note with intense bitterness in the aftertaste.

(swing-top-bottle) Clear, amber to copper colour with a rather short but also persistent and slowly lacing off-white foam. Sweet and chewy toast-malty aroma, with caramel, melanoidinic molasses and notes of herbal hops and a faint alcohol. Sweet flavour, full bodied with a mellow mouthfeel. Aromatic, well attenuated slightly roasted malt-character, nutty and minimal-fruity with herbal notes coming along early. Malty, sweet-bitter finish with distinctive herbal hoppy and well-integrated alcoholic notes. Superb, world-class Bock.

Bottle. Clear amber / red color with a small none lacing white head. Aroma is moderate malty, roasted, caramel, earth., notes of alcohol. Initial flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter, finish flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat, finish feel is light alcoholic.

Beautiful red-orange-amber colour; with yellowish, fast gone head. Earthy, chocolate, caramle, esters & some kind of heavy, dark & syrupy liqueur, ending in freshly kilned malt. Very good nose! Taste is again very earthy, leafy, lightly burned - at the edge of smoked - like very hotly, unsalted peanuts. A bitterish, more liquid version of Malay peanut sateh-sauce. A bit of sesam and chestnut cream mash flavours mixed in. No trace of the oversweet bready mold were used to; much more to the bitter side: part hops, but more roasted. Medium bodied, slightly silky texture, neither thick nor watery. Slightl burning MF. Superb example of Bockbier - great, Sebastian! Only one remark: either this is not a Heller Bock, or Im getting colourblind...

Flip-top bottle (from Landbierdealer) :  Clear, amber coloured, small and stable white head; complex nose: sweet caramelly maltiness and a resinous hoppy touch; medium bodied, well hidden alcohol, robust bitter-sweet flavour; soft MF, low carbonation; lasting bitter-aromatic, sweetish-toasted-malty, nearly a bit fruity finish with a lingering hoppiness in the aftertaste. Very well rounded and balanced Bock, extremely well quaffable. A splendid time is guarenteed for all......

Pours a clear amber color with a thin white head. Very good and pleasant aroma of malt, candied fruits, caramel and smoke. The flavor is also very good, the candied fruits and smoky malt are there but there is also a bitter and dry finish, I noticed also that the malt is earthy. The palate is light and oily and the carbonation is soft. This is a very interesting bock.

Any first impressions?
-A ring of head circles the clear orange-brown.
-Earthy caramel, cranberry and baccate fruitiness, and bean-like bock maltiness make up a sweet, confident aroma.
-Smoked nuts are laid out on wet earth, as fruity sweetness almost uses some oxidation to its advantage.
-The silky mouthfeel is never heavy, yet showcases a round maltiness to satisfy most malt heads Im sure.

What if you dig deeper?
-A trail of smoke is even perceived in the aroma.
-Grass blades offer flavor and bitterness in the back.
-A classic dunkel bock, well-crafted and flavorful, which must be a fine, fine product when released.

Bottle; best before May 06.

This chestnut colored lager grows a generous off-white head which lasts and leaves a good amount of lacing aroung the glass. Unfortunately expired since a few months, it starts to show signs of oxidation in a rotting nuts fashion, but nevertheless suggests a rich maltiness, accompanied by soft alcohol tones. Almonds and vague leafy hops constitute the finish while highly toasty and close to earthy malts dominate the entrance. Globally balanced, nutty, sweet and warming, while light-medium bodied and softly carbonated, but a bit tired at this stage and would be interesting to try fresher.
